I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  Bangladesh  for  the  additional  financing  of  the  Third  Primary 
Education Development Project.1  
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved the ongoing Third Primary Education 
Development  Project  for  SDR202,212,000  ($320  million  equivalent)  on  5  July  2011.2 The 
Government of Bangladesh, ADB, and eight other development partners jointly finance the 
government’s  6-year  (FY2012–FY2017)  Third  Primary  Education  Development  Program 
(PEDP3).3 The program focuses on improving student learning outcomes and completion rates, 
and reducing disparities across regions. The proposed additional financing will (i) deepen the 
ongoing reform agenda, (ii) scale up successful project interventions, and (iii) enable completion 
of scaled-up project activities under an extended period.  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Bangladesh  has  made  considerable  achievements  in  reducing  poverty  and  making 
progress on the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). The proposed additional financing will 
help support the momentum of PEDP3’s good performance toward achieving MDGs 2 and 3 
where all children, boys and girls alike, can complete a full course of primary schooling.4 
PEDP3’s approach is recognized globally as a successful model in enhancing government 
leadership  and  ownership  along  with  harmonized  support  from  development  partners.  All 
stakeholders, including the government and development partners, are committed to deepening 
the ongoing reforms articulated in the National Education Policy.5 
 
4.  PEDP3 supports four key reforms of the National Education Policy: (i) establishing an 
integrated school system under a framework that unifies public, nongovernment organization 
(NGO),  and  private  providers;  (ii)  improving  quality  through  reduced  class  size,  improved 
teaching  practices,  and  a  focus  on  information  and  communication  technology  literacy; 
(iii) decentralizing  primary  education  administration  and  management;  and  (iv)  engaging  in 
partnerships with NGOs and the private sector.  
 
5.  PEDP3 is supporting one of the largest primary school systems in the world, with over 
19.5 million children enrolled in 106,000 primary schools. It is making progress in improving 
access and retention in primary education. The net enrolment rate rose from 94.8% in 2010 to 
97.3% in 2013 and the completion rate increased from 60.2% to 78.6% over the same period. 
The  following  reforms  to  support  quality  education  have  been  successfully  implemented: 
(i) introduction of the diploma in primary education, and pilot testing and scaling up of innovative 
teaching–learning methods under the “Each Child Learns” program, are leading to improved 
teaching practice; (ii) a streamlined recruitment process has increased the number of qualified

and  female  teachers;  and  (iii)  the  Grade  5  Primary  Education  Completion  Examination  is 
becoming competency-based. 
 
6.  The joint midterm review (MTR) of PEDP3 conducted from June 2013 to September 
2014 confirmed that the innovative approaches of PEDP3 are yielding good progress:6  
(i)  A greater focus on results, with the use of the disbursement-linked indicator (DLI) 
incentive mechanism, where 24 of 27 DLIs have been achieved at the closing of 
the MTR, has shifted the nature of policy dialogue to focus on outputs, outcomes, 
and policy implementation, and to engage multiple and diverse stakeholders.7  
(ii)  Use of the treasury system and electronic procurement has strengthened the 
governance and accountability of these systems.  
(iii)  Harmonization among development partners has been at an exemplary level, 
with well-coordinated communication and review mechanisms, and joint decision 
making by all partners, showing the strength of the sector-wide approach. 
 
7.  Despite this progress, improvement of learning outcomes remains a major challenge. 
National student assessments conducted in 2011 and 2013 show low learning achievements, 
especially in Grade 5, with 25% of assessed students mastering Grade 5 competencies in 
Bengali (Bangla). In Grade 3, results are more encouraging, with 67% in 2011 and 74% in 2013 
mastering Grade 3 competencies in Bengali (Bangla). Learning achievements are lower among 
disadvantaged groups. Differences between schools and between rich and poor children are still 
high. The introduction of 1 year of publicly funded pre-primary education (PPE) in government 
primary  schools,  nationalization  of  35,000  registered  nongovernment  primary  schools,  and 
creation of an additional 26,000 teacher positions for the neediest schools are expected to help 
minimize the differences between schools and support disadvantaged children. The timeliness, 
quality,  and  coverage  of  the  annual  school  census  (the  core  monitoring  instrument  for 
measuring progress on all schools and students) have significantly improved. However, further 
measures are needed to improve usage of the census information to analyze, understand, and 
address disparities in student learning outcomes and retention. 
 
8.  Implementation progress and results are satisfactory, all safeguards requirements have 
been complied with, risks have been adequately managed, and the project was rated ‘on track’ 
since October 2013. PEDP3 meets the eligibility criteria for additional financing.8 
 
9.  ADB’s original financing was planned for the first 3 years of the program, with the 
agreement that additional financing would be made available if implementation was satisfactory. 
Given the positive outcome of the MTR and the government’s strong interest in deepening 
quality reforms with additional financing from several development partners, a joint decision was 
made by all partners to support extension of PEDP3 to maintain the momentum of progress. 
The proposed additional financing is expected to improve key performance indicators relating to

B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The impact of PEDP3 is quality education for all Bangladeshi children. The outcome of 
PEDP3 is an efficient, inclusive, and equitable primary education system delivering effective and 
relevant child-friendly learning to all Bangladesh’s children from pre-primary through Grade 5. 
The project’s expected impact and outcome remain consistent with the impact and outcome of 
PEDP3. As the original targets for two outcome indicators—net primary enrolment rate and 
years inputs per graduate—were achieved at MTR, higher targets have been set.  
 
C.  Outputs 
 
11.  PEDP3 has a common results framework that is subdivided into four broad results areas. 
These  four  interrelated  broad  results  areas  or  outputs  will  remain  the  same:  (i)  improved 
teaching and learning for all; (ii) reduced disparities and universal access and participation; (iii) 
decentralized and effective organization of the primary education system; and (iv) improved 
program planning and management. The nine annual DLIs are represented across these four 
broad results areas. During the MTR, progress for each broad results area was reviewed, and 
interventions and targets were agreed for the remaining program implementation period.10  
 
12.  The targets and indicators in the DLI matrix for the nine DLIs for years 4 and 5 are 
defined in alignment with the broad indicators outlined in the original program document. For six 
of the nine DLIs, new targets and indicators for year 6 were added to ensure that incentivizing 
performance continues through the end of the project. The agreed year 4 and 5 DLI targets 
were revised, reflecting the implementation experience from the first 3 years, and are more 
realistic than the original broadly defined targets.11  
 
13.  Output 1: Improved teaching and learning for all. The project supports (i) initiatives to 
enhance  student  performance  of  all  the  children  under  the  “Each  Child  Learns”  program, 
(ii) school  and  classroom-based  assessment,  (iii)  initiatives  to  strengthen  curriculum  and 
textbooks, (iv) timely production and distribution of quality textbooks to all eligible children, 
(v) gradual  introduction  of  information  and  communication  technology  in  education,  and 
(vi) activities to improve teacher education and development to ensure the learning of every 
child. The reforms, especially the “Each Child Learns” program and the diploma in education, 
will be completed, with more focus on systematic, continuous, and professional development of 
teachers and using information and communication technology in the classroom. The two DLIs 
for this output are (i) all requested textbooks distributed to all eligible schools on time, and 
(ii) the new diploma in education is provided in all 60 primary training institutes.

14.  Output 2: Reduced disparities and universal access and participation. The project 
supports (i) second chance and alternative education, (ii) 1 year PPE to children at age five, 
(iii) mainstreaming  inclusive  education,  (iv)  preparing  disaster-prone  areas  for  continuing 
schooling during emergencies, (v) implementing a communication framework and an action plan 
for social change strategy, (vi) school health for particularly needy children, (vii) enhanced 
school  physical  environment  based  on  actual  physical  conditions,  and  (viii)  needs-based 
infrastructure and furniture. A more targeted approach to address differences that still exist 
between schools and between students from different backgrounds will be applied. PPE will 
focus more on the neediest children; collaboration with civil society in providing PPE will be 
strengthened; and the quality of PPE will receive more attention. The process to identify sites for 
needs-based infrastructure will be improved, including improved water and sanitation facilities, 
and mechanisms to address hard-to-reach children will be strengthened and assessed. The two 
DLIs for this output are (i) quality of PPE improved and coverage of PPE expanded, and (ii) 
needs-based infrastructure implemented to achieve a pupil–usable classroom ratio of 56:1. 
 
15.  Output  3:  Decentralized  and  effective  organization  of  the  primary  education 
system. The project supports (i) strengthening of field level offices, (ii) decentralization of 
school  management  and  governance,  (iii)  school-level  leadership  development, 
(iv) organizational review and strengthening of field offices by creating and filling new positions 
and institutionalizing a career path, (v) improvement in the quality and reliability of the Grade 5 
terminal  examination,  (vi)  maintaining  efficient  recruitment  and  deployment  of  teachers, 
(vii) strengthening of the annual school census, and (viii) strengthening and institutionalizing the 
national student assessment. To strengthen district and subdistrict-level supervision and school 
level leadership and community support, decentralized levels will be given more flexibility in 
allocating funds. An additional 26,000 teacher positions have been created and these teachers 
will  be  placed  in  the  neediest  schools. The  output  has four  DLIs:  (i)  school management 
committees and district education offices implement decentralized education plans, (ii) Grade 5 
terminal examination is competency-based and its administration is enhanced, (iii) new teachers 
are recruited based on needs to meet the pupil–teacher ratio of 40:1 and using the existing fair 
and transparent recruitment system, and (iv) the annual school census covers all types of 
schools and improves accuracy and timeliness. 
 
16.  Output 4: Improved program planning and management. The project supports (i) the 
Ministry of Primary and Mass Education (MOPME) and Directorate of Primary Education (DPE) 
in managing PEDP3, (ii) implementation of the PEDP3 procurement and financial management 
(PFM) action plan, (iii) ensuring adequate sector financing to meet the requirements of PEDP3 
in line with the medium-term budgetary framework, (iv) strengthening monitoring functions, 
(v) strengthening human resource development, and (vi) promoting public–private partnership to 
engage relevant NGOs and the private sector. Strengthening of PFM will continue, and more 
focus  on  systematic  human  resource  development  and  improved  usage  of  public–private 
partnerships is planned. The DLI for this output is the primary education budget aligned with the 
program framework, consistent with the medium-term budgetary framework. 
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans  
 
17.  The  revised  cost  of  PEDP3  is  estimated  at  $9.808  billion  (Table  1).  The  original 
estimated  cost  was  $8.337  billion  using  the  2011  exchange  rate,  which  is  equivalent  to 
$7.476 billion using the 2015 exchange rate. The increase in total investment is $2.332 billion. 
During the MTR, the program costing was revised based on the required investments to achieve 
the targets agreed at MTR. Majority of the increase in allocation is in the government revenue 
budget,  caused  by  (i)  an  increase  in  pay  scale;  (ii)  nationalization  of  35,000  registered

5 
nongovernment primary schools; (iii) additional 26,000 teacher posts; (iv) 1-year extension; and 
(v) reallocation of cost categories, including textbooks, from development costs to revenue costs. 
All activities funded by the government revenue budget are essential to implement the reforms 
planned under PEDP3. Allocation in the development budget did not increase because of the 
(i) reallocation  of  cost  categories,  (ii)  rationalization  of  the  original  costing  based  on 
implementation experience, and (iii) activities that were originally planned to be integrated in 
PEDP3  in  the  later  years  remaining  outside  PEDP3  in  discrete  projects.  These  projects 
contribute to achieving the overall sector targets. However, as these projects have separate 
implementation arrangements and financing agreements, they are not funded by PEDP3.12

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  The MTR confirmed that the implementation arrangements agreed at the start of PEDP3 
will not be changed. The MOPME is the executing agency and the DPE is the key implementing 
agency. The MOPME will continue to lead overall coordination of the PEDP3 and the DPE will 
formulate  guidelines  and  plans;  and  implement,  supervise,  and  monitor  PEDP3.  For 
implementation of specific parts of PEDP3, other agencies at the national level will continue to 
be responsible. Detailed project management arrangements, as agreed with the government in 
the revised program document, are set forth in the project administration manual (PAM).13 
 
21.  Procurement  arrangements.  The  ADB  loan  proceeds  will  continue  to  be  used  to 
finance goods, works, and related services procured using national competitive bidding.14 Such 
procurement follows the government’s Public Procurement Act, 2006, and Public Procurement 
Rules, 2008, with modifications to and/or clarifications on the procedures agreed between the 
government, ADB, and other development partners as set out in the PAM, procurement plan,

Procurement  Guidelines  (2013,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Aside  from  ADB,  other 
development partners jointly finance goods, works, and related services procured using national 
competitive  bidding.  Based  on  the  performance  in  the  first  years  of  the  program,  specific 
capacity development actions have been agreed during MTR, as reflected in the PFM action 
plan, to continue mitigating risks and improving performance. After successfully pilot testing e-
procurement for works contracts under PEDP3, PEDP3 will support the Local Government 
Engineering  Department  and  the  Department  of  Public  Health  Engineering  to  expand 
e-procurement.  ADB  will  not  finance  any  goods  and  works  that  will  be  procured  using 
international  competitive  bidding,  as  this  will  follow  World  Bank  guidelines.  All  consulting 
services will be engaged using ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended 
from time to time). The World Bank will not finance consulting services.  
 
22.  Disbursement conditions and arrangements. The existing arrangement will continue. 
Funds  will  flow  from  ADB  to  the  government’s  consolidated  funds  based  on  withdrawal 
applications  submitted  by  the  DPE.  The  statement  of  expenditure  format  is  based  on 
semiannual interim unaudited financial reports, and is used for harmonized financial reporting 
and reimbursement. The interim unaudited financial reports reflect eligible expenditures. 
 
23.  ADB will continue to reimburse the government every 6 months in accordance with 
arrangements for the original loan: (i) 50% on achievement of annual DLIs that will be priced 
equally, submission of agreed reports, and receipt of statement of expenditure; and (ii) 50% on 
receipt of statement of expenditure. Disbursement schedules for the ongoing loan and the 
additional financing are harmonized to maintain this arrangement.15

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Economic and Financial 
 
25.  Economic  viability.  The  economic  analysis  provides  the  rationale  for  additional 
financing for the project, and assesses the benefits and costs associated with the additional 
financing.  The  project  investment  is  the  estimated  additional  cost  above  current  PEDP3 
spending. The benefits are related to changes in quantity and quality, and a reduction in the 
internal inefficiency of education produced over the period as a result of the PEDP3. The 
benefits are broadly assumed from two possible sources: (i) an increased number of primary 
school completers who earn higher wages (relative to non-completers), and (ii) an increased 
quality of education resulting in a higher wage premium for all primary school completers. Costs 
are associated with additional program costs from government and development partners as a 
result of the increased number of primary school teachers and increased salary levels. The 
additional financing will finance a 1-year extension of implementation until June 2017. The 
economic internal rate of return associated with this net present value is 18.8% for the whole 
program, which suggests that the additional financing under PEDP3 is an economically sound 
investment. 
  
26.  Fiscal sustainability. The long-run sustainability of the additional financing lies within 
the original framework of PEDP3, which depends on two factors: (i) adequate budget to the 
MOPME to maintain the investment plan, and (ii) continuity in the flow of improvements in 
quality and efficiency. The estimated resource envelope and the current gross domestic product 
growth trend indicate that it will not be difficult for the Ministry of Finance to allocate the required 
amount for PEDP3 (FY2015–FY2017). The allocation of a higher share of budget to primary 
education by the government is ensured since (i) the government’s national education policy 
proposes  a  significant  increase  in  budget  allocation  to  the  education  sector;  and  (ii) 
development  partner  support  is  linked  to  both  results  and  assurances  that  sector  budget 
allocations are in line with the medium-term budgetary framework. Efficiency gains are expected 
to benefit Bangladesh’s primary education sector as a result of the reforms being supported by 
PEDP3, including improved financial management, electronic procurement, and strengthened 
monitoring  and  evaluation,  which  also  keep  costs  down  while  improving  overall  education 
outcomes. These will continue reinforcing the long-term fiscal sustainability of Bangladesh’s 
primary education sector. 
 
B.  Governance  
 
27.  Financial due diligence work was carried out as part of the MTR and additional financing 
processing in accordance with ADB’s Financial Management and Analysis of Projects and

9 
Financial Due Diligence Methodology Note.16 This analysis confirmed that the chosen modality 
is sustainable. The overall fiduciary risk, although substantial, remains manageable as a result 
of the measures provided in the PFM action plan, supported by targeted technical assistance to 
improve government capacity, and is regularly updated following quarterly and annual fiduciary 
reviews and post-procurement audits.17 Based on the MTR recommendation, and upon request 
from the Government of Bangladesh, the deadline for sharing the annual audited program 
financial statements has been extended to 9 months after completion of each fiscal year. ADB’s 
Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with the 
government, MOPME, and DPE. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the PAM.  
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
 
28.  Positive effects of public investment in education and health, and NGOs’ contribution in 
economic and social empowerment activities, have contributed to significant improvement in 
poverty reduction in the 1990s and 2000s. Enrolment and retention are improving, but the 
school age children not enrolled in primary education (3%) are from the most disadvantaged 
backgrounds. PEDP3 will focus on implementation of the harmonized plans to ensure these 
children come to and stay in school. This will support providing PPE to the most needy, supply 
of free textbooks, tuition waivers, provision of second chance education, inclusive education, 
and quality improvements. MOPME will continue with the stipend and school feeding program. 
 
29.  Gender and development. Gender equity in primary school enrollment, retention, and 
in teacher recruitment in government primary schools has been achieved. However, efforts are 
needed to include gender and equity perspectives in all regular activities in primary education. A 
gender equity framework (gender action plan), which is part of the inclusive education action 
plan, has been implanted in the first years and has been updated for the remaining period.18 
The poverty, social, and gender due diligence for the original project still suffices, and gender 
categorizations and gender action plan commitments continue. 
 
D.  Safeguards 
 
30.  Environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous people. The project remains 
environment category B. The common harmonized environmental management framework was 
prepared at the start with the World Bank and reviewed, resulting in minor adjustments as part 
of  the  MTR  and  additional  financing  process.  Implementation  is  compliant  and  no  major 
changes were made. The project remains category B for both involuntary resettlement and 
indigenous  peoples’  safeguards.  The  common  harmonized  social  management  framework, 
which includes both aspects, was prepared at the start with the World Bank and reviewed 
thoroughly, with further strengthening in gender inclusiveness and the monitoring process as 
part of the MTR and additional financing. No major changes were made and implementation is 
compliant.  No  private  homesteads  will  be  acquired  nor  will  vulnerable  squatters  be  made 
homeless. The two joint frameworks harmonize ADB and World Bank safeguards policies, and 
show the exemplary development partner collaboration.

E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
31.  Among the key program implementation risks identified at the start, two remain prevalent. 
The first relates to inadequate institutional and personnel capacity to manage, implement, and 
monitor  the  PEDP3. The  project  combines  institutional  strengthening, decentralization,  and 
human resource development to increase the government’s institutional and personnel capacity. 
The  second  risk  relates  to  fiduciary  risks  associated  with  procurement  and  financial 
management. The project includes a strong joint fiduciary review mechanism by ADB and the 
World  Bank  in  close consultation  with  other  development  partners,  supported  by  technical 
assistance provided by different development partners including ADB to support strengthening 
of fiduciary oversight. Use of the treasury system by channeling of all development partner 
funds through the government’s treasury to finance PEDP3 eligible expenditures, including use 
of  the  integrated  budget  and  accounting  system  for  consolidated  reporting,  are  major 
achievements in financial management. The joint PFM action plan is in place to improve the 
fiduciary environment. The integrated benefits and impact of PEDP3 are expected to outweigh 
the costs. The risks and mitigating measures are described in detail in the risk assessment and 
risk management plan.19  
 
IV.  ASSURANCES 
 
32.  The government and the MOPME have assured ADB that implementation of the project 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and loan documents. 
 
33.  The government and the MOPME have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the 
project, which are set forth in the loan agreement.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
34.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of  
SDR87,533,000 to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the additional financing of the Third 
Primary Education Development Project, from ADB’s Special Funds resources; with an interest 
charge at the rate of 2% per annum during the grace period and thereafter; for a term of 25 
years,  including  a  grace  period  of  5 years;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the 
Board. 
 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President 
24 April 2015
